> I am a ham radio operator and I remember one receiver that I had that was a
> "black box" and completely software controlled. It was a Ten-Tec RX-320
> receiver, and it received LW/MW/SW in AM/CW/SSB. It was a fun little radio,
> but using the software to control it, there were so many other options
> available. Nice bandscope with point-and-click tuning. Selectable user
> defined filters, you name it. Another neat feature was the fact there there
> were virtually dozens of third-party software releases for operating it,
> usually catering to the ham/swl crowd.
>
> My thoughts are that perhaps a similar computer-controlled ghost box could
> be made. You could use the software to define sweep style, and it would be
> endless possibilities. You could have an RNG controlling the random sweep,
> and linear sweeps could be programmed to emulate triangle, sawtooth, ramp,
> etc...
>
> In addition, you could have on-the-fly recording options, and you could
> apply various filters to clean it up. Visual waveform indicators, and file
> reverse option for reversing the file. Heck, you could even introduce your
> preference of noise source (white, pink, brown) into the signal. Perhaps an
> optional echo chamber with built in mic for output. All of these things
> could be software controlled, and I am not to sure they couldn't be
> implemented via software package for existing radios out there such as the
> ICOM PCR-1000 or the TEN-TEC Rx 320 or Pegasus. Really all of these things
> are a result of the software interface, so it is completely possible, but it
> would have to be someone with a lot more tech experience than me to make it
> a reality. Any takers?
>
> thanks
> Andy
